results.title: Opus 3: variations on a random structure
results.creator_credit: Pierre Heberrt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film in which both sound and image were created with a minimum of photographic or electronic equipment. The images are a few simple geometric forms—squares, circles, lines, ellipses—arranged and counter-arranged to generate an increasing number of perceived images. Their appearance on the screen is as percussive as the sound that

results.title: Options
results.creator_credit: Howard Sturges, Jerry Aronson and Perspective Films
results.brief_description: Believing that people want to feel, hear and become involved in art, the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art, and its sister museums created “Options” - an exhibit meant to be touched and played with. It is a new approach to contemporary museums, involving more than just passive looking. The roving camera explores the reactions of the participants, and through the use of fast cuts, unusual angles and electronic music, the film becomes as involving an experience as the exhibit itself. Narrated by Ken Nordine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Howard Sturges, Jerry Aronson and Perspective Films

results.title: Optical Toy, Anamorphosis, French Emperor Napoleon III,  Walter Frères 1865
results.brief_description: Constellation: The anamorphic drawing presents a distorted perspective of Napoleon III that is corrected when reflected on a circular surface. Napoleon III declared himself emperor of France in 1851, bringing the Second Republic to an end. William Kentridge’s anamorphic animation refers to Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia under Mussolini when 275,00 Ethiopians lost their lives. The title highlights the recurring nature of history.
results.title_for_label: Optical Toy, Anamorphosis, French Emperor Napoleon III, Walter Frères 1865
results.description: Anamorphic illusion hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When viewed with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, with some even made to unveil their images when viewed from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of Cinemascope and widescreen in film.
description_for_label: Anamorphic illusion hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When viewed with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, with some even made to unveil their images when viewed from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of Cinemascope and widescreen in film.

results.title: Optical jig borers at work
results.creator_credit: Societe Genevoise D'Instruments de Physique and Montana Film Zurich
results.brief_description: A documentary on precision milling and boring machines. Opens by telling us the story of how a group of people created the “Societe Genevoise D’Instruments de Physique”, a society formed to create a way to measure using unit measurements. We then travel into the future to see how the dividing machines they originally created are working now.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Societe Genevoise D’Instruments de Physique and Montana Film Zurich

results.title: Optical Illusions
results.brief_description:
British illustrator Charles Henry Bennett pioneered comic illustrations techniques during the Victorian era. From 1856, he drew a series of caricatures for the Illustrated Times, informally known as ‘Shadows’. Inspired by popular magic lantern slides of the period, each scene depicts a shadow cast by an individual to form a surprising, usually humorous shape to reveal something about their inner personality.

The series was eventually published as a book, Shadow and Substance (1860), with hand coloured images matched with prose and poetry by Robert Brough, who Bennet had collaborated on the 1854 edition of Punch and Judy.

The series was eventually published as a book, Shadow and Substance (1860), with hand coloured images matched with prose and poetry by Robert Brough, who Bennet had collaborated on the 1854 edition of Punch and Judy.

results.title: Opposites attract
results.creator_credit: Elin Bakken Tonder and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
A shy retiring little man and his glamourous neighbour share meaningful looks as they pass each other in the hallway. He is entranced by her ravishing outfits, she is a little lonely and thinks ‘why not?’. But there is a twist in the tale of this claymation. Music by Matt Archer.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.
